sim_actions.name: Host CLI - APT34, BOOSTPIPE, Service Creation
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an attacker creating a new service on a Windows host. According to Mandiant Threat Intelligence, this command was seen in a previous campaign attributed to APT34. The binary seen in the campaign is part of the BOOSTPIPE malware family. 

BOOSTPIPE is a Windows service backdoor. The malware has similarity to FIREPIPE and SANDPIPE samples. This sample uses BOOST and HTTPS for its data transfer. The sample will store its parameters Base64 encoded as a command-line argument. More information on the malware used in the campaign can be read about in report: [20-00008142](https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/20-00008142).

Note: The binary used in this Action is benign and not a sample of BOOSTPIPE. This Action's purpose is to demonstrate the persistence method used by the malware family.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - DUEDLLIGENCE, DLL Side-Loading the DISM Utility
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates the DLL Side-Loading technique against a known Windows utility (Dism.exe). In this Action, a copy of the DISM tool residing on the target system is dropped into a folder with a custom version of DismCore.dll. When this copy of the DISM tool is executed, the tool will load the custom DLL file instead of the intended version of the DLL due to Windows DLL search order. If this library is loaded by the program successfully, the custom DLL will inject shellcode into the DISM process which executes the notepad application. More discussion about the use of the DLL Side-Loading technique being utilized by adversaries can be read about on the Mandiant blog [here](https://www.mandiant.com/blog/threat-research/2020/01/abusing-dll-misconfigurations.html).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - DUEDLLIGENCE, DLL Side-Loading the DISM Utility without Injection
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates the DLL Side-Loading technique against a known Windows utility (Dism.exe). In this Action, a copy of the DISM tool residing on the target system is dropped into a folder with a custom version of DismCore.dll. When this copy of the DISM tool is executed, the tool will load the custom DLL file instead of the intended version of the DLL due to Windows DLL search order. If this library is loaded by the program successfully, the custom DLL will execute the notepad application.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - Persistence through WMI Event Subscription, POWERSPLOIT
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an actor leveraging POWERSPLOIT's Persistence module to create a WMI event subscription to obtain persistence on the host.  A PowerShell script is leveraged to create the WMI event subscription as well as modify the PowerShell profile under $PROFILE.AllUsersAllHosts to include commands to execute once a new PowerShell process is created. 

The Event Filter is set to execute every day at 3 PM. At this time, an instance of PowerShell is spawned, which can be seen in the Command Line Event Consumer. When the PowerShell instance spawns, the contents of the PowerShell profile are read and executed. In this case, the command, which is base64 encoded, writes a text file to C:\Users\Public\Documents. 

According to Mandiant Threat Intelligence, APT groups, like APT41, have used POWERSPLOIT in previous campaigns to maintain persistence on a compromised host.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - APT29, EMPIRE, Token Privilege Escalation
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an attacker using PowerShell and EMPIRE to duplicate and impersonate the token of an another process. Adversaries may duplicate then impersonate another user's token to escalate privileges and bypass access controls. This tactic has been used by APT29 with malware such as SUNSPOT.

EMPIRE is a post-exploitation framework written in PowerShell. EMPIRE is commonly used to generate a stager payload, which is responsible for downloading and executing the framework's backdoor. The backdoor communicates via HTTP and HTTPS. Supported backdoor commands include shell command execution, PowerShell execution, and file transfer. The EMPIRE backdoor can also be extended via plugins. Supported plugins include remote desktop, screenshot capture, keylogging, lateral movement, credential theft, and reconnaissance. More information about EMPIRE can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--2c61638a-d5b0-53ae-a009-922395861239). More information on APT29 can be found of the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/actors/threat-actor--7a39953e-0dae-569a-9d49-d52a4a8865b1).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - EMPIRE, Named Pipe Client Impersonation
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates the execution of a script that creates a named pipe, and a service that writes to that named pipe. When the service connects to the named pipe, the script impersonates its security context. When executed successfully, the test displays the domain and name of the account it's impersonating (local SYSTEM).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - FIN7, Local Javascript Execution via WMI and Mshta
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates the Living Off the Land tactic of using executing local javascript via WMI to call mshta. FIN7 has been observed using WMI to call mshta and execute arbitrary javascript.

See more information about Living Off The Land tactics in [this report: 20-00009904](https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/20-00009904).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - LOCKBIT, Store Data in Registry Keys
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates how LOCKBIT stores information in the registry that is later used to identify the system that was encrypted. The keys are created in HKCU:\SOFTWARE\LockBit with values 'full' and 'Public'.

According to Mandiant Intelligence, LOCKBIT is ransomware written in C that encrypts files stored locally and on network shares. LOCKBIT can also identify additional systems on a network and propagate via SMB. Prior to encrypting files, LOCKBIT clears event logs, deletes volume shadow copies, and terminates processes and services that may impact its ability to encrypt files. LOCKBIT has been observed using the file extension ".lockbit" for encrypted files.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - POSHC2, Malicious HTA via VBScript GetObject
sim_actions.desc:
In this Action demonstrates a POSHC2 malicious MSHTA stager, coded in vbscript; using GetObject to locally compile and execute a CSharp based payload. The MSHTA Stager contains POSHC2 shellcode which is used to setup Implant communications. The method is demonstrated as follows;

`mshta.exe vbscript:GetObject("script:C:\Users\Public\Documents\Sharp_Posh_Stager.cs)(window.close)`

POSHC2 is a Powershell based C2 framework which allows basic to advanced C2 capabilities. POSHC2 allows a user to perform payload generation for initial access, setup custom persistence and define custom communication. POSHC2 is modular, and is easy to setup and use for maintaining access into target networks. Mandiant has observed POSHC2 used by a nexus of actors including APT33.

More information about this sample can be found on the Mandiant Threat Intelligence Portal in reports: [18-00017430] (https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/18-00017430) and [19-00004404] (https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/19-00004404)
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - UNC1189, PIECEMEAL, Disable AMSI
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates PIECEMEAL's technique to disable AMSI. 

PIECEMEAL is a PowerShell-based backdoor that downloads and executes additional PowerShell content in-memory for a variety of tasks including  persistence and anti-virus enumeration More information on PIECEMEAL can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--06e0f2db-4f9b-5d16-8bda-8f0acebbf629). More information on UNC1189 can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/actors/threat-actor--a31b9239-f356-5314-9495-a2e0de0abe5d).

NOTE: This Action requires AMSI to be enabled.

>**Pre-Requisites:**
Actor must have AMSI enabled
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 10 Actors as Non-admin, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 10 only, using Non-admin, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - APT41, ACEHASH, Mimikatz Variant
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates the execution of two files. They are the dropper and encrypted/compressed payload components, respectively, of a malware family known as ACEHASH. ACEHASH is a credential theft and password dumping utility that combines the functionality of multiple tools such as Mimikatz, hashdump, and Windows Credential Editor (WCE).

Upon placing c64.exe and F64.data on the system, the attacker runs the command

c64.exe f64.data "9839D7F1A0 -m"

This specific command provided a password of "9839D7F1A0" to decrypt the contents of F64.data, and a switch of "-m", indicating the attacker wanted to replicate the functionality of Mimikatz. With the correct password provided, c64.exe loaded the decrypted and decompressed shellcode into memory and harvested credentials.

More information on this sample can be found on Mandiant's Blog: [GAME OVER: Detecting and Stopping an APT41 Operation](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2019/08/game-over-detecting-and-stopping-an-apt41-operation.html).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - APT41, ACEHASH, WCE Variant
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates the execution of two files. They are the dropper and encrypted/compressed payload components, respectively, of a malware family known as ACEHASH. ACEHASH is a credential theft and password dumping utility that combines the functionality of multiple tools such as Mimikatz, hashdump, and Windows Credential Editor (WCE).

Upon placing c64.exe and F64.data on the system, the attacker runs the command

c64.exe f64.data "9839D7F1A0 -w"

This specific command provided a password of "9839D7F1A0" to decrypt the contents of F64.data, and a switch of "-w", indicating the attacker wanted to replicate the functionality of WCE. With the correct password provided, c64.exe loaded the decrypted and decompressed shellcode into memory and harvested credentials.

More information on this sample can be found on Mandiant's Blog: [GAME OVER: Detecting and Stopping an APT41 Operation](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2019/08/game-over-detecting-and-stopping-an-apt41-operation.html).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - DUMPERT, Dumping LSASS
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates a host attempting to dump LSASS using open source tool DUMPERT. 

DUMPERT is a relatively new post-exploitation tool to dump lsass.exe using direct system calls to evade user-mode API hooks used by security products. This tool demonstrates the use of direct System Calls and API unhooking and combine these techniques in a proof of concept code which can be used to create a LSASS memory dump using Cobalt Strike, while not touching disk and evading AV/EDR monitored user-mode API calls. More information on DUMPERT can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--d223bcea-e737-5f4a-9562-4d1390510b0b).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - FGDUMP
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates an in-memory attack of the Local Security Authority Subsystem.  FGDUMP injects a DLL containing hash dumping code and records the output for extraction.  Additionally, FGDUMP attempts to kill local antivirus software before attempting to dump password hashes.  The functionality for FGDUMP is quite broad and includes the ability to dump hashes as another user (valid credentials are required), or even a remote host (IP address and valid credentials are required).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - GSECDUMP, Credential Dumping
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates how a malicious actor can extract LANMAN and NTLM hashes with GSECDUMP. This information can be used to login to other accounts or used in NTLM pass-the-hash attacks.

According to Mandiant Intelligence, GSECDUMP is a publicly available utility used to obtain hashes from the Windows registry, including the SAM file, cached domain credentials, and LSA secrets. More information on GSECDUMP can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--c0f31e20-d739-54c5-9034-6f4db7231dc6). 

Please note, the GSECDUMP application used in this Action is removed by Action cleanup.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows 10, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows 10, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - INTERNALMONOLOGUE, Credential Access
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an attacker using the credential stealer, INTERNALMONOLOGUE to extract passwords. INTERNALMONOLOGUE invokes a local procedure call to the NTLM authentication package (MSV1_0) from a user-mode application through SSPI to calculate a NetNTLM response in the context of the logged on user, after performing an extended NetNTLM downgrade.

Please note, the Internal Monologue application used in this Action is removed by Action cleanup.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - METASPLOIT, Nishang Get-PassHashes
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates a malicious attacker using Nishang's Get-PassHashes cmdlet to extract the hashes from a compromised machine.  This Action uses a modified powerdump script from the METASPLOIT Framework to dump password hashes.  The hashes could then be cracked offline for persistence or lateral movement.

Credit for this script goes to [samratashok](https://github.com/samratashok/nishang), David Kennedy and Zer1t0.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - MIMIKATZ (2.2.0), Variant #2
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates how a malicious actor can extract passwords with MIMIKATZ (2.2.0). In this Action, the "sekurlsa::logonpasswords" module is used to obtain plain-text passwords and NTLM hashes from lsass.exe. This information can be used to login to other accounts or used in NTLM pass-the-hash attacks. The variant of MIMIKATZ used in this Action was compiled from public source code on May 26, 2020.

Please note, the MIMIKATZ application used in this Action is removed by Action cleanup.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - pwdump7
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates the use of PWDUMP7, a Windows password dumper developed by Andres and Miguel Tarasco.  This tool extracts the binary SAM and System files and then pulls the hashes from those files.  These hashes can then be cracked offline using rainbow tables, dictionary attacks or brute force methods.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - RUBEUS, Kerberoast, .NET Version 4.5
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an attacker attempting to use RUBEUS to perform a Kerberoast attack by retrieving a TGS ticket from a user with a Service Principal Name set which contains the password hash of the user. Due to the nature of what this Action is testing, it will need to be run on an Actor that is configured with Active Directory and a user profile that is a valid domain account.

The RUBEUS binary used in this Action was compiled using .NET Framework Version 4.0.

RUBEUS is a C# toolset for raw Kerberos interaction and abuses. More information on RUBEUS can be found at the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--76dd491b-1e9d-5b83-b727-455609de7ed0).

>**Pre-Requisites:**
Actor must be domain-joined to properly configured Active Directory environment
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - SHARPDUMP, Dumping LSASS
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates a host attempting to execute a SHARPDUMP binary to dump running memory from LSASS to a file.

SHARPDUMP is a C# port of PowerSploit's Out-Minidump.ps1 functionality. The MiniDumpWriteDump Win32 API call is used to create a minidump for the process ID specified (LSASS by default) to C:\Windows\Temp\debug.out, GZipStream is used to compress the dump to C:\Windows\Temp\debug.bin (.gz format), and the original minidump file is deleted.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - WSHRAT, Keylogging
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates WSHRAT Keylogging behavior on a Windows host. In this Action, a module similar to WSHRAT is executed to log user keystrokes. This behavior mimics the behavior of the 2019 variant on the WSHRAT malware. WSHRAT.VBSCRIPT is a VBScript subversion of WSHRAT, a scripted remote access Trojan (RAT) based on the Houdini code family that can be built in either JavaScript or VBScript. The malware includes information about the compromised system in the User-Agent field of the HTTP header in beacons to its command and control (C&C) server. The C&C server responds with commands, which are parsed and executed. WSHRAT has typical RAT functionality such as command-line and script execution, downloading and executing programs, and password theft and is capable of executing additional modules that enable remote desktop, file manager, and keylogging.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows 7, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2016 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - SHARPVIEW, System Discovery, Variant #1
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates how an attacker can use SHARPVIEW to conduct system discovery on a previously compromised system. This Action queries user event data and returns it via stdout.

SHARPVIEW is a custom C# implementation of the PowerShell tool, PowerView. SHARPVIEW does not have one-to-one feature parity with PowerView.

It is recommended that this action be run as only Admin for Server 2016, or Admin and System on Windows10. If Server 2016 is run as System, it will error.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - Mshta to Command and Control
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an Actor using the "mshta.exe" utility to execute a HTML Application (HTA) payload. mshta.exe is a Windows binary which is used to run interactive HTA programs. However the HTA specification allows for scripting languages such as VBScript and JScript. This scripting ability can be leveraged by attackers to execute malicious programs, including shellcode. 

Since the calling process of the HTA is mshta.exe, which is signed by Microsoft, this method of payload execution can serve as an application whitelist bypass technique. Upon successful execution of this payload the victim creates a reverse TCP connection via port 80 to a fictitious IP of 10.10.10.10.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - Active Directory Reconnaissance with SHARPHOUND, CollectionMethod All
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates a malicious actor leveraging the tool SHARPHOUND to collect information on a targeted Active Directory. This Action uses the "--CollectionMethod All" which collects a variety of information on the AD, including group memberships, local admin, ACLs, Remote Desktop users, and more. The data is then outputted to a zip file, presumably to stage the file for exfiltration. 

SHARPHOUND is the data ingestion utility used by newer versions of BLOODHOUND to collect information about an Active Directory environment. SHARPHOUND is written in C# and re-implements BLOODHOUND's older PowerShell-based data ingestion utility. More information about SHARPHOUND can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--a5b93cd1-4b2d-57ef-bd0d-fbc70b77b3e5).

>**Pre-Requisites:**
Actor must be domain-joined to properly configured Active Directory environment
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - Active Directory Reconnaissance with SHARPHOUND, CollectionMethod All, PowerShell Variant
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates a malicious actor leveraging the tool SHARPHOUND to collect information on a targeted Active Directory. This Action uses the "CollectionMethod All" which collects a variety of information on the AD, including group memberships, local admin, ACLs, Remote Desktop users, and more. Note: This Action leverages the PowerShell variant of SHARPHOUND. 

SHARPHOUND is a C# rewrite of the BloodHound Ingestor.

SHARPHOUND is the data ingestion utility used by newer versions of BLOODHOUND to collect information about an Active Directory environment. SHARPHOUND is written in C# and re-implements BLOODHOUND's older PowerShell-based data ingestion utility. More information about SHARPHOUND can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--a5b93cd1-4b2d-57ef-bd0d-fbc70b77b3e5).

>**Pre-Requisites:**
Actor must be domain-joined to properly configured Active Directory environment
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - ColdCryptor POC Execution, Variant #1
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates an attempt to execute a tool used to drop and encrypt files for testing ransomware controls. In this Action a non-malicious VRT (Validation Research Team) modified version of the poc ransomware script tool ColdCryptor is used to drop 50 text files into three "msv" labeled directories. The tool will then encrypt and change the extension of the files. The clean up command will clean up the files and registry keys that were set.

Note - The original source code for ColdCryptor can be found on Github under the name `coldencryptor.cs`
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - WSHRAT, Privilege Escalation
sim_actions.desc: This Action demonstrates WSHRAT privilege escalation behavior on a Windows host. In this Action, a script is executed which contains a method for elevating user permissions. If this command is successful, notepad is executed. This behavior mimics the behavior of the 2019 variant on the WSHRAT malware. WSHRAT.VBSCRIPT is a VBScript subversion of WSHRAT, a scripted remote access Trojan (RAT) based on the Houdini code family that can be built in either JavaScript or VBScript. The malware includes information about the compromised system in the User-Agent field of the HTTP header in beacons to its command and control (C&C) server. The C&C server responds with commands, which are parsed and executed. WSHRAT has typical RAT functionality such as command-line and script execution, downloading and executing programs, and password theft and is capable of executing additional modules that enable remote desktop, file manager, and keylogging.
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 Actors as SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows Server 2019, Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, Windows 7 only, using SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.

sim_actions.name: Host CLI - MIMIKATZ (2.2.0), Download Obfuscated File by Appending to JPEG to Disk
sim_actions.desc:
This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download a variant of the MIMIKATZ tool, saving it to disk, and executing it. This sample is obfuscated by appending the script to a legitimate image. 

MIMIKATZ is a credential stealer written in C that targets Windows authentication credentials. Techniques employed include stealing password hashes, keys, and Kerberos tickets. Credentials can be printed to the console or saved to disk. MIMIKATZ also supports privilege escalation, extracting credentials from the Windows Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) and Security Account Managers (SAM) database, and service manipulation. More information about MIMIKATZ can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--bf2fc1e5-7850-5ecd-87a7-263e6da5708d).
sim_actions.notes:
Mandiant Security Validation recommends running this Action on Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10 Actors as Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin users.

Compatible Operating Systems and User Profiles: This Action is compatible with Windows 11, Windows Server 2019, Windows 10 only, using Non-admin, SYSTEM, Admin. This Action may not work properly on non-compatible Operating Systems or with non-compatible user profiles and clean-up commands may not execute.
